Issues.Title: fix(compiler): limit the number of chained instructions
Issues.Body:
Some Angular template instructions that follow each other may be chained together in a single expressions statement, containing a deeply nested AST of call expressions. The number of chained instructions wasn't previously limited, so this could result in very deep ASTs that cause stack overflow errors during TypeScript emit.

This commit introduces a limit to the number of chained instructions to avoid these problems.

Closes #57066

Issues.Title: Resolver function with SSR executed twice, on server and on client
Issues.Body:
### Command

other

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

In an Angular project with SSR enabled and client hydration provided, I use a resolver function to fetch some data (titles, metadata, breadcrumbs, etc.). To show a progress indicator, I listen for the router events of type ResolverStart and ResolverEnd only on the client while this data is being fetched.

Scenario 1: When the page is requested from the app, everything works as expected -> ResolverStart is raised -> a request is sent to the backend and once completed -> ResolverEnd is raised.

Secenario 2: The problem occurs when the URL of the page is entered in the browser (or when refreshing the page) and the server has to render the page. The server actually manages to call the resolver function, fetch the data and send it to the client. However, as soon as the application starts, the entire chain repeats itself -> ResolverStart is raised -> Resolver function is executed -> ResolverEnd is raised. The only difference is that in this scenario the resolver function does not actually send a request to the Beckend, but uses the hydrated data.

This seems unnecessary as the users are already waiting while the server fetches the data from the backend, and I expect them to be shown the entire page and not the loading spinner for a fraction of a second that makes the page flicker.

I believe that the resolver function in scenario 2 should only be executed on the server and the ResolverStart and ResolverEnd should not be triggered on the client. What are your thoughts on this?

### Minimal Reproduction

1. Add resolver function to any route which calls an http get request.
2. Subscribe to the router events in order to show loading indicator between RosolverStart and ResolverEnd events only on the client
```
constructor() {
    afterNextRender(() => {
        this.isLoading$ = this.#router.events.pipe(
            filter((e) => e instanceof ResolveStart || e instanceof ResolveEnd),
            tap((e) => {
                console.log(e instanceof ResolveStart)
            }),
            map((e) => e instanceof ResolveStart)
        );
    });
}
```

Issues.Title: Allow caching HTTP requests when URLs differ between server and client
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

common, platform-browser, platform-server

### Description

As a result of #53702 and #50117, a new token `HTTP_TRANSFER_CACHE_ORIGIN_MAP` was added to allow mapping internal origins to external origins. However, this does not go far enough and fails to account for situations where entire paths are different between server and client. This can happen (such as in my case) when the server is in a Docker network and has direct access to other services and the browser uses a reverse proxy that allows access to the same service through path rewrites based on some known prefixes.

For example, `/api/foo` may be routed to an internal service and rewritten as `http://my-service:3000/foo`. Thus, the server needs to call `http://my-service:3000/foo` and the browser needs to call `/api/foo`. The difference between them is more than just the origin.

This same issue was mentioned in multiple comments (see below), but the final solutions that introduces `HTTP_TRANSFER_CACHE_ORIGIN_MAP` is somehow more limiting than the needs that were articulated. See the following comments and several others:

[#50117 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50117#issuecomment-1792077410)
[#50117 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50117#issuecomment-1832556707)

Scouring the above-mentioned issues and others, I could not find a way to address this use case, which means the transfer cache will never work for my setup.

### Proposed solution

There are several possible ways to solve this:

1. A new token similar to `HTTP_TRANSFER_CACHE_ORIGIN_MAP` that would allow mapping path prefixes rather than just origins.
2. A way to override the cache key as suggested in #53702, [#50117 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50117#issuecomment-1792077410), [#53702 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/53702#issuecomment-1898089674) and several others.
3. A way to compose the current root interceptor with additional functionality, though this is quite heavy-handed and may lead to unintended consequences.

### Alternatives considered

Current alternative is to use `HTTP_TRANSFER_CACHE_ORIGIN_MAP` and change the network setup to accommodate the limitation of only being able to map origins and not paths. However, this is quite disruptive, and I would rather not make a change this big to accommodate the limitations of the frontend framework.

I had also attempted to use my own interceptor to rewrite URLs, similar to [#50117 comment](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/50117#issuecomment-1602675046), but this won't work as explained in the same comment.

One last option is to not rely on the transfer cache at all through `withNoHttpTransferCache()`, but this is effectively what's happening in my case without doing anything anyway.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow caching HTTP requests when URLs differ between server and client" (#57080)

Issues.Title: Moving projected content into another DOM element is not getting destroyed when they should, causes a memory leaks
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

I need to move the content of the host component into an external DOM element (created by a 3rd party library).

So the new content wrapper is not accessible until the 3rd party library generates it, only then the content of the host component should be moved into that new content wrapper. these content could be components such as `<mat-table>`.

The content is moved successfully to the new content wrapper and works properly, however, the problem is when the host component is destroyed, the content components don't seem to be destroyed! causing a memory leak.

See the attached video of the heap snapshot below.


Component template:

```html
<ng-content/>
```
Component code:

```ts
ngOnInit(): void {
  // Move all content of the viewport into the content wrapper
  const childNodes: ChildNode[] = Array.from(viewportElement.childNodes);
  childNodes.forEach((node: ChildNode) => this.renderer.appendChild(contentWrapperElement, node));

  // Append the content wrapper to the viewport
  this.renderer.appendChild(viewportElement, contentWrapperElement);
}
```

Source code: https://github.com/MurhafSousli/ngx-scrollbar/blob/ebc3409abdc5afa3a8d74b45a960bf49a6d80e45/projects/ngx-scrollbar/src/lib/ng-scrollbar-ext.ts#L125-L130

Issues.Title: ng serve does not allow us access to raw 'index.csr.html' when using SSR
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

If I go to `http://localhost:4200/`, I get a transformed html response which includes my lazy-loaded router-component for the `''`path. This is as expected during SSR.

However,
If I go to `http://localhost:4200/index.html`, I expect to get an html response which is exactly the index.html on disk, without the ssr transformation. But the dev server sends me a "404 Not Found" instead.

Turns out that, for SSR, angular creates 2 index.html - `index.csr.html` and `index.server.html`. I am interested in the csr version, because I want to precache it.

However, the angular dev server's middleware prevents me from accessing that file.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/992adb0f-9f59-4813-9321-2bdd17d36eb0)

This is a screenshot of me debugging the dev-server. The request was for `/index.html`

In line 25, the middleware tries to search the outputFiles for 'index.html'. The problem is that the outputFile don't have 'index.html'. They have 'index.csr.html' and 'index.server.html'. As a result, `rawHtml` is going to be always be `undefined`, and the middleware is  going to go to line 27 and skip the middleware.

If I try to go for `/index.csr.html`, then the middleware will skip out before it even reaches Line 25, due to the `if` condition on Line 12
Line 12 says that any request that are not '/' or '/index.html' will be ignored. 

So we are perpetually denied being served the raw `index.html` while serving in SSR


### Minimal Reproduction

Create a new angular app
Add SSR to it as per the documentation
Add a lazy loaded component for the path `''` with the selector `test-element` and an empty template, 
Remove the contents of app.component's template and add a router outlet to app.component.html
Do other task necessary to set up routing
Serve the app with ng serve

Go to `http://localhost:4200` and check the response that came on first load. You should see the element `<test-element></test-element>` in the html. This is ok

Go to `http://localhost:4200/index.html`. This should result in 404 Not Found. This is ok.

Go to `http://localhost:4200/index.csr.html`. This should result in 404 Not Found. This is not ok. It should have returned html without the test-element in it.

### Command

### Description

The Angular cli refuses to build a project with error "TS2345: Argument of type ... is not assignable to parameter of type ...", even though Typescript itself is able to correctly deduce that no type issue is occurring. This issue occurs with RxJS.

```
      map(obj => obj.id),
      filter(id => id != null),

    ).subscribe();

  doSomethingWithId(id: number): void {
    console.log(id);
  }
```

Issues.Title: serve: trailing slash added to static files does not take query string into account
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

This is more or less a continuation of #27949. I was testing the fix for that issue in Angular 18.1.0 and found that it is still not working. And since I cannot reopen that issue I'm writing this new one.

Whenever I try to access a static file without a trailing slash, angular returns a redirect to the same path with a trailing backslash. 
```
Get: /oauth2redirect

Status: 301
location: /oauth2redirect/
```

**But if the path contains a query string, then the trailing backslash is added to the end of the query string**:
```
Get: /oauth2redirect?code=xxx&scope=yyy&state=zzz

Status: 301
location: /oauth2redirect?code=xxx&scope=yyy&state=zzz/
```

So I end up in an infinite redirect loop that ends with a `ERR_TOO_MANY_REDIRECTS` error and the following URI:

```
/oauth2redirect?code=xxx&scope=yyy&state=zzz///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
```

Currently the wasm plugin introduced in v18.1.0 resolves not only `.wasm` imports, but any imports that end with `(any character)wasm`. It must be a typo in the wasm plugin regex `/.wasm$/` which should look like `/\.wasm$/`.

You can see it in this [example](https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-jfbg7u?file=src%2Fmain.ts) by running `ng build`.
In the example above `matrix-js-sdk` depends on `@matrix-org/matrix-sdk-crypto-wasm` which is treated as a wasm import by the plugin which causes build error

```
The plugin "angular-compiler" didn't set a resolve directory for the file "angular:wasm:init:/home/projects/stackblitz-starters-nnuphq/node_modules/@matrix-org/matrix-sdk-crypto-wasm/pkg/index.js", so esbuild did not search for "./matrix_sdk_crypto_wasm_bg.wasm.js" on the file system.
```

## What is the new behavior?

<!-- Please describe the new behavior that. -->

Wasm plugin resolves only `.wasm` imports.
